{{about|the Christian communities|other uses|Twelve Tribes (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox Christian denomination | name = Twelve Tribes | image =Twelve_Tribes_Logo.jpg | imagewidth = 283 | alt = | caption = | main_classification = [[Messianic Judaism]]{{request quotation|date=August 2018}}
[[Christian Fundamentalism]]
[[New religious movement|Christian new religious movement]] | orientation = | polity = | structure = [[Apostolic Council]] | leader/moderator = | leader = | fellowships = | associations = | area = North America, South America, Western Europe, Australia | website = http://www.twelvetribes.com | founder = Elbert "Gene" Spriggs | founded_date = 1972 | founded_place = [[Chattanooga, Tennessee]], United States | separated_from = | parent = | merger = | separations = | hospitals = | nursing_homes = | aid = | congregations = | members = 2,500–3,000{{cite news | first=Christine | last=Legere |authorlink= | title=Sect to increase holdings Plan would link harbor, downtown | date=2009-06-04 | publisher=Globe Newspaper Company | url =http://www.boston.com/news/local/massachusetts/articles/2009/06/04/plymouth_plan_would_link_waterfront_downtown/?page=2 | work =Boston Globe |page=2 | accessdate = 2009-11-04 }} | ministers = | missionaries = | temples = | primary_schools = | secondary_schools = | tertiary = | footnotes = }} The '''Twelve Tribes''', formerly known as the '''Vine Christian Community Church''',{{cite news | first= | last= |authorlink= | title=Church to sell Yellow Delis, other properties and relocate | date=1979-03-26 | publisher= WEHCO Media | url = | work =Chattanooga Times}} '''Northeast Kingdom Community Church,'''Palmer, Susan J. ''Apostates and Their Role in the Construction of Grievance Claims Against the Northeast Kingdom/Messianic Communities'' article in the book ''The Politics of Religious Apostasy: The Role of Apostates in the Transformation of Religious Movements'' edited by David G. Bromley Westport, CT, Praeger Publishers, (1998). {{ISBN|0-275-95508-7}} the '''Messianic Communities''', and the '''Community Apostolic Order''' is an international confederation of religious communities{{cite news | first=Angeljean | last=Chiaramida | authorlink= | title=Tall Ships tie up in Salisbury for weekend festival | date=2009-07-29 | publisher=Eagle Tribune Publishing Company | url=http://www.newburyportnews.com/punews/local_story_203231819.html | archive-url=https://archive.is/20130129161605/http://www.newburyportnews.com/punews/local_story_203231819.html | dead-url=yes | archive-date=2013-01-29 | work=Newbury port Daily News | accessdate=2009-11-04 }} founded by Gene Spriggs (now known as Yoneq) that sprang out of the [[Jesus movement]] in 1972 in [[Chattanooga]], [[Tennessee]].{{cite journal|title=The Northeast Kingdom Community Church of Island Pond, Vermont: Raising Up a People for Yahshua's Return|journal=Journal of Contemporary Religion|date=May 1997|first=Susan J.|last=Palmer|author2=Bozeman, John M.|volume=12|issue=2|pages=181–190|doi= 10.1080/13537909708580798|url=http://www.informaworld.com/smpp/content~db=all~content=a794457154~tab=content|accessdate=2009-11-05 }} The group is an attempt to recreate the [[Apostolic Age|1st-century church]] in the [[Acts of the Apostles|Book of Acts]];{{cite news | first=Mark | last=Barna |authorlink= | title=Twelve Tribes living as one | date=2009-07-29 | publisher=Freedom Communications | url =http://www.gazette.com/articles/twelve-45677-tribes-springs.html | work =Colorado Spring Gazette | accessdate = 2009-11-04 }} the name "Twelve Tribes" is also derived from a quote of the [[Paul of Tarsus|Apostle Paul]] in Acts 26:7.{{cite news | first= | last=Twelve Tribes |authorlink= | title=Our Twelve Tribes: a Manifesto | date=Summer 2004 | publisher=Parchment Press | url =https://twelvetribes.org/articles/confederation-twelve-tribes-manifesto | work =The Voice: Call to Restoration |page=2 | accessdate = 2009-12-06 }} The group has also been referred to as ''The Yellow Deli People''{{cite news | first=Wes | last=Shultz |authorlink= | title=Remembering the Yellow Deli People | date=2008-05-07 | publisher=Chattanooga Publishing Company, Inc. | url =http://www.chattanoogan.com/articles/article_128124.asp | work =Chattanoogan | accessdate = 2009-12-06 }} and informally as ''The Community''. ==History== The origins of the Twelve Tribes movement can be traced to a ministry for teenagers called the "Light Brigade"{{cite news | first=Gary | last=Warth |authorlink= | title=The 12 Tribes at a glance | date=2009-10-03 | publisher=Lee Enterprise | url =http://www.nctimes.com/news/local/valley-center/article_a68bc3cf-981d-5250-9525-e064a002bf1d.html | work =North County Times | accessdate = 2009-11-11 }} in 1972. The ministry operated out of a small [[Coffeehouse|coffee shop]] called "The Lighthouse" in the home of Gene Spriggs and his wife Marsha. The Light Brigade began living communally{{cite book | last = Hunt | first = Stephen | authorlink = Stephen J. Hunt | title = Christian Millennialism | publisher = Indiana University Press | year = 2001 | location = Bloomington and Indianapolis, Indiana | pages = 209–223 | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = 978-0-253-21491-1 }} and opened a restaurant called "The Yellow Deli" while attending several churches, before deciding on the [[First Presbyterian Church (Chattanooga, Tennessee)|First Presbyterian Church]]. The Light Brigade, while at First Presbyterian, caused friction with the establishment by bringing in anyone who was willing to come with them, including members of different [[social classes]] and [[Race (classification of human beings)|racial groups]], a practice not engaged in at that time. On January 12, 1975, the group arrived at First Presbyterian only to find out that the service had been cancelled for the [[Super Bowl]], this led the group to form The Vine Christian Community Church. During this time, the church "planted" churches, each with its own Yellow Deli, in [[Dalton, Georgia|Dalton]] and [[Trenton, Georgia]]; [[Mentone, Alabama]]; and [[Dayton, Tennessee]]. [[File:Island Pond raid.jpg|thumb|180px|Northeast Kingdom Community Church members leaving the courthouse with their children on June 22, 1984]] Their withdrawal from the religious mainstream turned what had been a friction-filled relationship into an outcry against them. They began holding their own services, which they called "Critical Mass" in [[Warner Park (Chattanooga)|Warner Park]],{{cite journal|title=The Twelve Tribes: Preparing a Bride for Yahshua's Return |journal=Nova Religio|date=February 2010|first=Susan J.|last=Palmer|volume=13|issue=3|pages=59–80|doi= 10.1525/nr.2010.13.3.59|url=|format=}} appointing elders{{cite news | first=Alan | last=Murray |authorlink= | title=Vine elders concede church has authoritarian character | date=1978-01-19 | publisher=Chattanooga Publishing Company, Inc. | url = | work =Chattanooga Times}}{{cite news | first=Bill | last=Castel |authorlink= | title=Elder: "We have no money" | date=1980-12-01 | publisher=Chattanooga Publishing Company, Inc. | url = | work =Chattanooga Times}} and baptizing people outside any denominational authority. The deteriorating relationship between the group and the religious and secular Chattanooga community attracted the attention of [[FREECOG|The Parents' Committee to Free Our Children from the Children of God]] and the [[Citizen's Freedom Foundation]] who labeled the church a "[[cult]]" and heavily attacked Spriggs as a cult leader. This led to what the group refers to today as the "Cult Scare"{{cite news | first=Eddie | last=Wiseman |authorlink= | title=Cult Scare in Chattanooga | date=Spring–Summer 2009 | publisher=Parchment Press | url =http://www.twelvetribes.com/pdf/freepapers/vine-house-days.pdf | work =In the Vine House Days |page=10 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101130185621/http://twelvetribes.com/pdf/freepapers/vine-house-days.pdf |archive-date=2010-11-30 | accessdate = 2009-11-06 }} in the late seventies. A series of [[deprogrammings]] starting in the summer of 1976 that were carried out by [[Ted Patrick]].{{cite news | first=Joan | last=Garret | authorlink= | title=Chattanooga: Yellow Deli hosts reunion, betrothal | date=2008-05-03 | publisher=Chattanooga Publishing Company, Inc. | url=http://www.timesfreepress.com/news/2008/may/17/chattanooga-yellow-deli-hosts-reunion-betrothal/ | work=Chattanooga Times Free Press | accessdate=2009-11-07 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110305034837/http://www.timesfreepress.com/news/2008/may/17/chattanooga-yellow-deli-hosts-reunion-betrothal/ | archivedate=2011-03-05 | df= }} The group nevertheless largely ignored the negative press and the wider world in general, and continued to operate its businesses opening the [[Areopagus]] and a second local Yellow Deli in downtown Chattanooga.{{cite news | first= | last= |authorlink= | title=Yellow Deli In Comeback Popular Christian Eatery From 1970s To Be Revived | date=2006-04-05 | publisher=John Wilson | url =http://www.chattanoogan.com/articles/article_83232.asp | work =Chattanoogan | accessdate = 2009-11-08 }} In 1978 an invitation was received from a small church in [[Island Pond, Vermont]] for Spriggs to minister there; the offer was declined but the group began moving in stages to the rural town, naming the church there The Northeast Kingdom Community Church. One of Patrick's last deprogramming cases in Chattanooga occurred in 1980; it involved a police detective who, according to Swantko, had his 27-year-old daughter arrested on a falsified warrant in order to facilitate her deprogramming, with the support of local judges.{{cite journal|doi=10.1023/A:1022021125576|title=The Twelve Tribes' Communities, the Anti-Cult Movement, and Government's Response|journal=Social Justice Research|year=2000|first=Jean|last=Swantko|volume=12|issue=4|pages=341–364|id=|url=http://www.twelvetribes.com/pdf/appendixes/social-justice.pdf|format=|accessdate=2009-11-09|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081203175836/http://www.twelvetribes.com/pdf/appendixes/social-justice.pdf|archivedate=2008-12-03|df=}} The group continued moving, closing down all of its Yellow Delis and associated churches except for the one in Dalton. At one point, a leader conceded that the group was deeply in debt before closing the Dalton church down and moving the last members to Vermont. [[File:Common Sense Island Pond.jpg|left|thumbnail|Common Sense Cafe and Yellow Deli in Island Pond, Vermont; owned and operated by Twelve Tribes.]] The move to Vermont, combined with an initial period of economic hardship, caused some members to leave. The Citizen's Freedom Foundation conducted several meetings in [[Barton, Vermont|Barton]] to draw attention to the group. The Citizen's Freedom Foundation had made allegations of mind control in Chattanooga, but now it made accusations of [[child abuse]]. In 1983, charges were brought against Charles "Eddie" Wiseman (an elder in the group) for [[misdemeanor]] [[assault|simple assault]]; this, combined with multiple child custody cases, formed the basis for a search warrant. On June 22, 1984 [[Vermont State Police]] and [[Vermont Social Rehabilitation Services]]{{cite journal|doi=10.2307/3512176|title=Media Coverage of Unconventional Religion: Any "Good News" for Minority Faiths? |journal=Review of Religious Research|date=December 1997|first=Stuart A.|last=Wright|volume=39|issue=2|pages=101–115|id= |format=|jstor=3512176 }} seized 112 children; all were released the same day because the raid was ruled unconstitutional.{{cite news | title=Children of Sect Seized in Vermont | date=1984-06-24 | url =https://www.nytimes.com/1984/06/23/us/children-of-sect-seized-in-vermont.html | work =The New York Times | accessdate = 2009-11-12}} Due to what the group perceived were a massive misunderstanding of the events and concerns leading up to and surrounding the raid, its members began formal relationships with their neighbors. Two months after the raid, the case against Wiseman fell apart after the main witness recanted, saying he was under duress from the [[anticult movement]]. The case was later dropped in 1985 after a judge ruled that Wiseman had been denied his right to a [[speedy trial]]. Eddie Wiseman's public defender, Jean Swantko, who had been present during the raid, later joined and married Wiseman.{{cite news | first=Scott | last=Wheeler |authorlink= | title=The Raid on Island Pond 25 Years Later – A Personal Look | year=2009 | publisher=Scott Wheeler | url =http://www.thekingdomhistorical.com/index.php/latest-news/210-the-raid-on-island-pond-25-years-later.html | work =Northland Journal | accessdate = 2010-02-26 }} [[File:Peacemaker1.jpg|thumbnail|right|Peacemaker 1 bus at a June 22, 1984 Raid anniversary in Island Pond, Vermont.]] By 1989, the church had become widely accepted in Island Pond{{cite news | first= | last=| title=Vt. Village Warms to Church | date=1989-07-05 | publisher=[[Tribune Company]] | url=| work =The Hartford Courant |page=17}} and grew substantially during the 1980s and 1990s, opening branches in several different countries, including [[Canada]], [[Australia]], [[Brazil]], [[Spain]], [[Germany]], [[Argentina]], and the [[United Kingdom]]. During this expansion phase, the group used the name Messianic Communities, before deciding to rename itself The Twelve Tribes. Through the mid-2000s (decade), the group remained controversial, with accusations of [[child labor]],{{cite news | first=Kenneth | last=Lovett |authorlink= | title=Upstate 'Soap' Cult fined for Child Labor | date=2001-10-04 | publisher=[[News Corporation]] | url =http://www.nypost.com/p/news/upstate_soap_cult_fined_for_child_Eoi0z2cBQc5W4LlE1al4FK | work =New York Post | accessdate = 2009-12-15 }} [[Child abduction#Parental child abduction|custodial interference]], and illegal [[homeschooling]].{{cite news | title=Fundamentalist Christian Group Gets School of Their Own | date=2006-08-31 | url =http://www.dw-world.de/dw/article/0,,2151809,00.html | work =Deutsche Welle | accessdate = 2009-11-17 }} In 2006 the group held a reunion for members and friends of the Vine Christian Community Church and the former Yellow Deli in Warner Park, announcing a new community in Chattanooga.{{cite news | first=Robert T. | last=Nash |authorlink= | title=Chattanooga Yellow Deli Reunion Draws Crowd | date=2006-04-16 | publisher=Chattanooga Publishing Company, Inc. | url =http://www.chattanoogan.com/articles/article_83886.asp | work =Chattanoogan | accessdate = 2009-11-17 }} The movement proceeded to open a new Yellow Deli in 2008, nearly 30 years after leaving Chattanooga. ==Beliefs and practices== The Twelve Tribes' beliefs resemble those of [[Christian fundamentalism]], the [[Hebrew Roots]] movement, [[Messianic Judaism]] and the [[Sacred Name Movement]]; however the group believes that all other [[Christian denominations|denominations]] are fallen, and it therefore refuses to align itself with any denomination or movement. They believe that in order for the messiah to return, the Church needs to be restored to its original form seen in [https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Acts+2%3A38-42&version=CJB Acts 2:38–42] and [https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Acts+4%3A32-37&version=CJB Acts 4:32–37]. This restoration is not merely the restoration of the 1st-century church, but the creation of a new Israel consisting of Twelve Tribes in twelve geographic regions. Part of this restoration is the return to observing the [[Shabbat|sabbath]], maintaining some of the [[613 Mitzvot|Mosaic law]]{{cite news | first=Heather | last=Stephenson |authorlink= | title=A church of their own | date=2000-09-10 | publisher=Herald Association | url= | work =Rutland Herald}} including dietary laws, and the festivals.{{cite news | first=Gary | last=Warth |authorlink= | title=VALLEY CENTER: Twelve Tribes Christian community lives as an example of its faith | date=2009-10-04 | publisher=Lee Enterprise | url =http://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/news/2009/oct/04/valley-center-twelve-tribes-christian-community/ | work =North County Times | accessdate = 2009-12-13}} This interpretation of the prophesied restoration of Israel, combined with the perceived immorality{{cite news | first= | last=Twelve Tribes | authorlink= | title=If the Foundations Are Destroyed, What Can the Righteous Do? | date=Fall 2004 | publisher=Parchment Press | url=http://www.twelvetribes.com/pdf/freepapers/love-is-splendored.pdf | work=Love is a Many Splendored thing | pages=9–12 | accessdate=2009-12-12 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101130193309/http://twelvetribes.com/pdf/freepapers/love-is-splendored.pdf | archivedate=2010-11-30 | df= }} in the world leads the group to believe that the end times has arrived, though no date has been set.{{cite news | first=Kim | last=Folstad |authorlink= | title=Life on the Farm | date=2000-12-02 | publisher=Cox Enterprises | work =Palm Beach Post | pages =9–12}} One noted aspect of the group is its insistence on using the name "[[Yahshua]]", as opposed to [[Jesus]]. Because the name "Yahshua" represents the nature of Jesus, the group similarly bestows upon each member a Hebrew name that is meant to reflect the personality of the individual.{{cite news | first=Matt | last=Stearns |authorlink= | title=Disciples maintain a life of simplicity – Despite controversy, – group lives quietly | date=2002-01-06 | publisher=[[The McClatchy Company]] | url =| work =[[The Kansas City Star]] | pages =B1}} The group believes there are ''Three Eternal Destinies''.{{cite news | first= | last=Twelve Tribes | authorlink= | title=Three eternal Destinies of Man | date=June 2001 | publisher=Parchment Press | url=http://www.twelvetribes.org/pdf/freepapers/3ED7.pdf | work=The Three Eternal Destinies | pages=9–22 | accessdate=2009-12-07 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080516185927/http://www.twelvetribes.org/pdf/freepapers/3ED7.pdf | archivedate=2008-05-16 | df= }} It believes that after the [[Fall of Man]] every person is given a [[conscience]]; and that after dying every person goes to a state of being called death (in Hebrew Sheol and Greek Hades){{cite news | first= | last=Twelve Tribes | authorlink= | title=The Passion of the Christ The Rest of the Story | date=Spring 2004 | publisher=Parchment Press | url=http://www.twelvetribes.com/pdf/freepapers/the-passion-revised.pdf | work=The Passion of the Christ : The Rest of the Story | page=7 | accessdate=2009-12-12 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081230081257/http://www.twelvetribes.com/pdf/freepapers/the-passion-revised.pdf | archivedate=2008-12-30 | df= }} regardless of faith. Upon the [[second coming]], believers will be brought back for the thousand years to reign with "Yahshua" before the last judgment. At the end of this millennium, all of the nonbelievers will be judged according to their deeds and put into one of two groups: the righteous and the filthy/unjust. The filthy and the unjust will be sent to the [[Lake of fire|Lake of Fire]] while the righteous will go on into eternity and fill the universe. [[File:TT-literature.jpg|thumb|right|"We Need Radical Change" an example of Twelve Tribes "free paper" commonly distributed at events as a form of Evangelism]] The leadership within is structured as a series of Councils which consists of local councils, regional councils, and a global Apostolic Council; the group is also overseen within these councils by a fluid number of teachers, deacons, deaconesses, elders and apostles.{{cite book | last = Palmer | first = Susan J. | authorlink = Susan J. Palmer | title = Children in New Religions | publisher = Rutgers University Press | date = 1999-06-01 | location = New Brunswick, NJ | pages = 153–171 | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = 978-0-8135-2620-1 }} Gene Spriggs is highly regarded as the first person to open up his home to brothers and sisters, but members state that he is not regarded as a spiritual figurehead.{{cite book | last = Palmer | first = Susan J. | authorlink = Susan J. Palmer | title = Moon Sisters, Krishna Mothers, Rajneesh Lovers | publisher = Syracuse University Press | year = 1994 | location = Syracuse, New York | pages = 133–153 | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = 978-0-8156-0382-5 }} The group operates as a 501 (d) – "for-profit organization with a religious purpose and a common treasury." The community pays property taxes, but the 501d structure tends to result in no income tax liability. Courtship within the Community involves a "waiting period"{{cite news | first=David | last=Filipov |authorlink= | title='Forgiven and free' | date=2009-06-28 | publisher=Globe Newspaper Company | url =http://www.boston.com/news/local/massachusetts/articles/2009/06/28/religious_group_opens_its_ship_peacemaker/?page=1 | work =Boston Globe | accessdate = 2009-12-27}} in which the man or woman expresses their desire to get to know the other person. The couple then receives input from the community while spending time together. The couple is [[betrothed]] (engaged) if their parents (or the entire community, if they are adults) confirm their love and compatibility; the couple is then permitted to hold hands. Weddings are dramatized pre-enactments{{cite encyclopedia |last=Palmer |first=Susan J. |authorlink= Susan J. Palmer |editor=James R. Lewis |encyclopedia=The Encyclopedia of Cults, Sects and New Religions |title=Messianic Communities/North East Community Church |url= |accessdate= |edition=1st |year=1998 |publisher=Prometheus Books |volume=1 |location=Amherst, New York |id= |doi= |pages=334–335 |quote= }} of what the group believes will happen at the end of time when "Yahshua" returns to earth for his [[Bride of Christ|bride]]. Children have been noted to play a central role in the group's eschatological beliefs, because future generations of the group will be the "144,000" of Revelation 7. Children are [[homeschooled]]. Within the group, teenagers may take on apprenticeships in the group's [[Putting-out system#Cottage industry|cottage industries]] to be taught trades complementing their education.{{cite news | first= | last=Staff Writer |authorlink= | title=Tribes speak, but don't apologize | date=2001-04-13 | publisher=[[MediaNews Group]] | url =| work =[[Bennington Banner]]}}{{cite news | title=Healing Buildings and Healing Souls in the Catskills | url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9503E5DA173FF937A15754C0A9639C8B63 | accessdate=2009-10-28 | work=The New York Times | first=Fred A. | last=Bernstein | date=2005-07-24}} The group utilizes corporal punishment with a "reed-like rod" like a balloon stick (a minimum) {{cite news | first=Brad | last=Pokorny |authorlink= | title=Island Pond has message for Media: Paint Brighter Picture or Get Lost | date=1985-02-24 | publisher=[[New York Times Company]] | url =| work =Boston Globe |page=32 }} across the child's bottom. ==Controversies== {{Expand section|date=January 2010}} Since its inception, the group has ignited controversy and garnered unfavorable attention from the media, the [[anti-cult movement]] and governments. [[New England Institute of Religious Research]]'s Executive Director the Rev. Bob Pardon{{cite web|url=http://www.neirr.org/instte.html |title=About NEIRR |accessdate=2009-12-31 |last=The New England Institute of Religious Research |work=The New England Institute of Religious Research Website |publisher=The [[New England Institute of Religious Research]] }} warns in his report that "Messianic Communities, under the leadership of Spriggs, has tended towards an extreme authoritarianism and a "Galatian heresy."{{cite web | title=My Analysis of the Twelve Tribes | work=New England Institute of Religious Research website | url=http://www.neirr.org/conclusn.html | accessdate=2005-10-23 }} The Tribes have responded with a line-by-line response to the report and they continue to contend its large "errors, distortions, misunderstandings, and misjudgments", while criticizing the heavy use of apostates in his report.{{cite web | title=Our Response to the NEIRR Analysis | work=Twelve Tribes: Controversies | url=http://www.twelvetribes.com/pdf/appendixes/neirr-response.pdf | accessdate=2009-10-29 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080706155610/http://www.twelvetribes.com/pdf/appendixes/neirr-response.pdf | archivedate=2008-07-06 | df= }} In France, the group was listed on the 1995 Governmental Report by the [[Parliamentary Commission on Cults in France]] under the name "Ordre apostolique – Therapeutic healing environment."{{cite web | title=French National Assembly: On Sects | url=http://www.assemblee-nationale.fr/12/rap-enq/r3507.asp | accessdate=2008-05-09 }} Twelve Tribes members Jean Swantko and husband Ed Wiseman have made efforts to combat social stigma and the [[anti-cult movement]] by engaging in dialogue with [[Apostasy|hostile ex-members]],{{Citation needed|date=June 2014}} the media and government authorities.{{cite encyclopedia | last = Palmer | first = Susan J. | authorlink = Susan J. Palmer | editor = Lindsay Jones | encyclopedia = Encyclopedia of Religion | title = Twelve Tribes | edition = 2 | year = 2005 | publisher = Macmillan Reference USA | volume = 14 | location = New York |page=9409}} Swantko has presented at scholarly conferences including [[CESNUR]]{{Cite journal | first = Jean | last = Swantko-Wiseman | title = State-Sanctioned Raids and Government Violations of Religious Freedom: Revealing Similarities of Constitutional Errors in Both the 1984 Island Pond Raid and the 2008 FLDS Raid | publisher = The 2009 CESNUR Conference | place = Salt Lake City, Utah | year = 2009| id = | url = http://www.cesnur.org/2009/slc_wiseman.htm | postscript = {{inconsistent citations}}}} [[Communal Studies Association]]{{cite web | url = http://www.usi.edu/libarts/communal/2010CSA-Abstracts.pdf | title = Communal Studies Association, 2010 New Harmony, Indiana | accessdate = 2010-12-13 | year = 2010 | format = PDF | publisher = Communal Studies Association | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110720193424/http://www.usi.edu/libarts/communal/2010CSA-Abstracts.pdf | archivedate = 2011-07-20 | df = }} and [[Society for the Scientific Study of Religion]]{{cite web | url = http://www.sssrweb.org/pdf/2010SSSRRRAprogramv3.pdf | title = Society for Scientific Study of Religion and Religious Research Association Annual Meeting 2010 | accessdate = 2010-12-13 | year = 2010 | format = PDF | publisher = Society for Scientific Study of Religion and Religious Research Association Annual}} as well as a chapter in [[James T. Richardson]]'s ''[[Regulating Religion: Case Studies from Around the Globe]]''. The Twelve Tribes has been cited by [[Stuart A. Wright]] as a group suffering from "Front-End/Back-End Disproportionality" in media coverage. According to Wright, the media often focuses on unsubstantiated charges against the group, but as charges are investigated and as cases fall apart, the media covers them significantly less at the end than it does at the beginning. Wright then asserts that this leaves the public with the impression that the group was guilty of the disproven charges. ===Commentary on the Island Pond raid=== The Island Pond raid has remained prominent in Vermont legal history; it was the subject of a [[Vermont Bar Association]] seminar in 2006.{{cite web |url=http://www.vtbar.org/Upload%20Files/WebPages/cle/archivelist/2006programs/2006seminar/2006MidYear/5island.pdf |title=Vermont Bar Association 49th Mid-Year Meeting |accessdate=2010-01-08 |last=Vermont Bar Association |format=PDF |publisher=Vermont Bar Association |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101222060917/https://vtbar.org/Upload%20Files/WebPages/cle/archivelist/2006programs/2006seminar/2006MidYear/5island.pdf |archivedate=2010-12-22 |df= }} The group held anniversary events in both 1994{{cite magazine | first=Yvonne | last=Daley | authorlink= | title=Praise the Lord: the community goes forth to meet the world | date=1994-06-19 | publisher=[[Herald Association]] | url=http://www.twelvetribes.org/pdf/appendixes/940619-vt-sun-mag.pdf | magazine=Vermont Sunday Magazine | accessdate=2010-01-11 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110728135254/http://www.twelvetribes.org/pdf/appendixes/940619-vt-sun-mag.pdf | archivedate=2011-07-28 | df= }} and 2000;{{cite news | first= | last=New York Times |authorlink= | title=Island Pond Journal; Trip Home to Stand Up For Their Community | date=2000-06-19 | publisher=[[New York Times Company]] | url =https://www.nytimes.com/2000/06/19/us/island-pond-journal-trip-home-to-stand-up-for-their-community.html?pagewanted=1 | work =New York Times | accessdate = 2010-01-10 }} and [[film producer|produced]] a 75-minute documentary.{{cite news | first=Peter | last=Freyne |authorlink= | title=When Big Brother Ran Vermont | date=2005-07-27 | publisher=[[Seven Days (newspaper)|Seven Days]] | url =http://www.7dvt.com/2005/when-big-brother-ran-vermont | work =Seven Days | accessdate = 2010-01-10 }} The Vermont Chapter of the [[ACLU]] also criticized the raid, calling it "frightening" and "the greatest deprivation of civil liberties to have occurred in recent Vermont history."{{cite news | first=Colin | last=Smith |authorlink= | title=ACLU: Raid on Sect was Lawless act by Vermont | date=1984-06-26 | publisher=[[New York Times Company]] | url = | work =Boston Globe}} The then-Governor of Vermont, [[Richard Snelling]], who had authorized the raid, reportedly drew the "hottest political fire of his career" in the weeks after{{cite news | first=Colin | last=Nickerson |authorlink= | title=Island Pond Case: How Much Latitude Does the Church have? | date=1989-07-25 | publisher=[[New York Times Company]] | url =| work =Boston Globe }} Vermont Attorney General [[John J. Easton, Jr.]] attributed the raid to assisting his campaign for governorship.{{cite news | first=Michael | last=Kranish |authorlink= | title=Governor's Race a nail biter, Legislature Might Decide winner | date=1984-06-26 | publisher=[[New York Times Company]] | url = | work =Boston Globe}} In 1992, [[John Burchard]], who had been the State Commissioner of Social and Rehabilitation Services, and [[Vanessa L. Malcarne]], published an article in ''[[Behavioral Sciences and the Law]]'', encouraging changes in the law that would have allowed the raid to succeed.{{cite journal|doi=10.1002/bsl.2370100108|title=Investigation of Child abuse/Neglect in Religious Cults|journal=Behavioral Sciences and the Law|year=1992|first=John D.|last=Buchard|author2=Malcarne, Vanessa L.|volume=10|issue=|pages=75–88|id= |url=|format=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.boulderweekly.com/article-5583-father-son-holy-toast.html|title=Father, son & holy toast - Boulder Weekly|date=12 May 2011|publisher=|accessdate=17 October 2017}} ===Teachings about Jews === It teaches that the [[Jews]] were [[Jewish deicide|guilty of the blood of Christ]], quoting [https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=matthew+27%3A25&version=CJB Matthew 27:25].{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2000/jul/03/race.religion | location=London | work=The Guardian | first=Jeevan | last=Vasagar | title=Racist sect digs in at rock festivals | date=2000-07-03}}{{cite web|url=http://twelvetribes.org/articles/who-does-pope-think-he|title=Who Does the Pope Think He Is?}} Although often labelled [[antisemitic]], the group repeatedly denies this accusation. Its members keep the [[Sabbath]] and the Jewish festivals of [[Pesach]], [[Yom Kippur]], and [[Sukkot]]. Youth have [[Bar Mitzvah]] and Bat Mitzvah celebrations, and they regularly perform Israeli folk dances.{{cite news | location = Bennington, VT | work=Bennington Banner | first=Neal | last=Goswami |title=Let Us Pray: Twelve Tribes, honoring the past}} ===Child labor and homeschooling controversies=== In 2001, ''[[The New York Post]]'' ran an article accusing the group of [[child labor]] violations;{{cite news | first=Katy | last=Moeller |authorlink= | title=Worshippers of Yahshua as savior weather storm – Cambridge farm counters criticism | date=2001-04-15 | publisher=[[John E.N. Hume III]] | url =| work =Daily Gazette | pages =A–01}}{{cite news | first= | last=Associated Press |authorlink= | title=Twelve Tribes sect opens farm to Press group Denies Charges of Child Labor, Racism | date=2001-04-14 | url = | work =Watertown Daily Times |page=29}} and later attributed itself as having prompted the investigation.{{cite news | first=Jeane | last=MacIntosh |authorlink= | title=State probes cult in Child Labor Scandal on heels of post report | date=2001-04-09 | publisher=[[News Corporation]] | url =http://www.nypost.com/p/news/state_probes_cult_post_child_labor_ejnbb0yjhckbYDg0QWMiJK | work =New York Post | accessdate = 2010-01-03 }} The Twelve Tribes responded with a [[press conference]] at the ''"Commonsense Farm"'' where the alleged child labor had taken place.{{cite news | first= | last=Staff Writer |authorlink= | title=Tribes speak, but don't apologize | date=2001-04-13 | publisher=[[MediaNews Group]] | url =| work =Bennington Banner}} The Twelve Tribes reported that during a random inspection by [[Estée Lauder Companies]], the company discovered that several 14-year-olds had been found assisting their fathers in their [[cottage industry]]; this report was later confirmed by Estée Lauder who terminated their contract with Common Sense products. The group's official statement at the press conference stated that they believed that it was a [[family-owned business]], and children ought to be able to help their parents in the business while making "no apology" for it. The [[New York State Department of Labor]] stated that they intended to visit all five of the Twelve Tribes' businesses. State Attorney General [[Eliot Spitzer]] asserted that apprenticeships amounted to [[indentured servitude]] and were illegal. [[Robert Redford]]'s [[Sundance Group#Sundance Catalog|Sundance Catalog]], who had contracted with Common Wealth Woodworks (another of the group's cottage industries that made furniture), also terminated their contract as a response to the allegations. The Labor Department found no violations at Common Sense Farm or Commonwealth Woodworks. They did fine two other industries $2,000 for a 15-year-old pushing a [[wheelbarrow]] and another 15-year-old changing a [[lightbulb]]. In Germany and France, the controversies centered on the issues of homeschooling, health, child abuse, and religious freedom. The group has several times been in conflict with authorities in Germany and France over homeschooling their children, with a particularly long and protracted dispute between the community in [[Klosterzimmern]], in the municipality of [[Deiningen]], [[Bavaria]], and Bavarian education authorities.{{cite book|author=Jean A. Swantko|editor=James T. Richardson|title=Regulating religion: case studies from around the globe|chapter=The Twelve Tribes Communities, the Anti-Cult Movement, and Governmental Response|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=U6opyVE_IYkC&pg=PA197|accessdate=27 August 2011|year=2004|publisher=Springer|isbn=978-0-306-47886-4|pages=197–199}} Homeschooling is illegal in Germany, with [[Homeschooling in Germany|rare exceptions]]. When fines and arrests failed to have an effect on the community, authorities granted the group the right to operate a private school on the commune's premises, under state supervision. The agreement entailed that the school would not teach [[sex education]] and [[evolution]].{{cite news | author=Alexander Görlach | title=Sieg der Sekten-Eltern | work=Die Welt | url=https://www.welt.de/print-welt/article195835/Sieg_der_Sekten_Eltern.html | accessdate = 2011-08-26 | date = 2006-02-04 }}{{cite news | last=cpa/jol/dpa | title=Schulboykott. "Zwölf Stämme" erhalten eigene Schule | work = Der Spiegel | date = 2006-08-29 | url = http://www.spiegel.de/schulspiegel/wissen/0,1518,434193,00.html | accessdate = 2011-08-26 }} ==Police raids in Germany== On September 5, 2013, German police raided two communities belonging to the Twelve Tribes and removed 40 children to protect them from alleged continued abuse.{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-23977577 | work=BBC News | title=German Christian sect raided and children put in care | date=2013-09-05}} The group admits that they use a "reed-like rod" for discipline, but denies abusing their children. {{cite news | author=Jamie Merrill | title='It is our right to use the willow cane': Inside the Twelve Tribes Christian fundamentalist sect at centre of childcare controversy | work=The Independent | url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/it-is-our-right-to-use-the-willow-cane-inside-the-twelve-tribes-christian-fundamentalist-sect-at-centre-of-childcare-controversy-8820271.html |accessdate = 2013-09-17 | date = 2013-09-16 | location=London}} The religion sociologist [[Susan J. Palmer|Susan Palmer]] pointed out that the doctors found no evidence of mistreatment in September 2013 following the police raids.Erich Mayer, FOREF Europe, [http://www.ots.at/presseaussendung/OTS_20150107_OTS0004/deutschland-kontroverse-um-zwoelf-staemme-soziologin-warnt-vor-gezielter-desinformation-durch-sektenexpertenc Kontroverse um „Zwölf Stämme“ – Soziologin warnt vor gezielter Desinformation durch Sektenexperten], APA-OTS, 2015-01-01 ==Outreaches== [[File:12Tribes bus.jpg|thumb|'Hippie Bus' in California]] The Twelve Tribes utilizes mobile operations and vehicles to evangelize at various events. * [[Peacemaker (ship)|Peacemaker Marine]] — a Class-A [[barquentine]] sailing ship bought and restored by the group sailing on the Eastern coast of the United States. The group now gives tours and evangelizes at ports.{{cite web|url=http://savannahnow.com/node/625617|title=''Savannah Now'' article|last=Felty|first=Dana Clark|date=2008-11-29|publisher=''Savannah Morning News''|accessdate=2008-12-23}} * [[Peacemaker (bus)|Peacemaker I&II Buses]] {{cite news | first=Christine | last=Wallgren |authorlink= | title=A festival of peace Twelve Tribes opens its Plymouth home to curious neighbors | date=2006-07-23 | publisher=Globe Newspaper Company | url =http://www.boston.com/news/local/massachusetts/articles/2006/07/23/a_festival_of_peace/ | work =Boston Globe | pages =1–3 | accessdate = 2009-11-04 }} * A First Aid tent is set up at various events by the group.{{cite news | first=Christopher | last=Dreher |authorlink= | title=The Doomsday Prophets on Main Street | date=2005-10-23 | publisher=Globe Newspaper Company | url =http://www.boston.com/news/globe/magazine/articles/2005/10/23/the_doomsday_prophets_on_main_street/ | work =Boston Globe | accessdate = 2009-11-10 }} ==See also== * [[Anabaptism]] * [[Exclusive Brethren]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Twelve Tribes Communities}} ;Movement Links at the Twelve Tribes YouTube Channel] ;Critical of Twelve Tribes *[http://www.neirr.org/mcconclu.html Twelve Tribes Report by the New England Institute for Religious Research] {{about|the goddess|the legendary bird|Huma bird|the Tibetan script|Umê script|the villages in Iran|Umay, Iran (disambiguation){{!}}Umay, Iran}} [[File:Хуртуях-тас.jpg|thumb|The ritual feeding of an Umay idol in [[Khakassia]], Russia]] {{Infobox deity | type = Turkic | name = Umay | god_of = [[Fertility]] | abode = Sky | symbol = | parents = [[Kayra]] and [[Yer Tanrı]] | siblings= [[Erlik]]
[[Ülgen]]
[[Koyash]]
[[Ay Tanrı]] }} '''Umay''' (also known as '''Umai'''; in [[Old Turkic]]: [[File:Old Turkic letter Y1.svg|10px]][[File:Old Turkic letter M.svg|10px]][[File:Old Turkic letter O.svg|10px]]; {{lang-kk|Ұмай ана}}, ''Umay ana''; {{lang-ru|Ума́й / Ымай}}, ''Umáj / Ymaj'') is the goddess of fertility {{cite book |last=Cotterell |first=Arthur |author2=Rachel Storm |title=The Ultimate Encyclopedia of Mythology |year=1999 |publisher=Lorenz Books |location=New York |isbn=0-7548-0091-1 |pages=466, 481}} in [[Turkic mythology]] and [[Tengriism]] and as such related to women, mothers and children. Umay resembles earth-[[mother goddess]]es found in various other world religions. ==Etymology== In [[Mongolic languages|Mongolian]], ''Umai'' means 'womb' or 'uterus'. The [[earth]] was considered a "mother" symbolically. The [[Turkic languages|Turkic]] root ''umāy'' originally meant 'placenta, afterbirth', and this word was used as the name for the goddess whose function was to look after women and children, possibly because the placenta was thought to have magic qualities.{{cite book|last=Clauson|first=Gerard|title=An Etymological Dictionary of Pre-Thirteenth Century Turkish|year=1972|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=Oxford|pages=164–165|authorlink=Gerard Clauson}} Literally in the [[Mongolian language]], "eje" or "eej" means "mother," and in Old Turkic, the word ''eçe'' also means 'mother'.{{Clarify|date=December 2017|reason=Which Mongolian? Is there, for "umay" or "eje", really any verifiable connection to Turkic, or vice versa, regarding the language groups may not be closely related, and if, which connection? Words might be similar by coincidence more often than a layperson may think.}} == Goddess of Children == The name appeared in the 8th-century [[Orkhon inscriptions|inscription]] of [[Kul Tigin]] in the phrase ''Umay teg ögüm katun kutıŋa'' 'under the auspices of my mother who is like the goddess Umay'. Umay is a protector of women and children. The oldest evidence is seen in the [[Orkhon script]] monuments. From these it is understood that Umay was accepted as a mother and a guide. Also, [[khagan]]s were thought to represent [[Tengri|Kök Tengri]]. Khagan wives, ''katun''s or ''hatun''s, were considered Umays, too. With the help of 'Umay, ''katun''s had babies, and these babies were the guarantee of the empire. According to ''Divanü Lügat’it-Türk'', when women worship Umay, they have male babies. [[Turkic peoples|Turkic]] women tie strings attached with small cradles to will a baby from Umay. This belief can be seen with the [[Tungusic peoples]] in Southern [[Siberia]] and the [[Altay people]]. Umay is always depicted together with a child. There are only rare exceptions to this. It is believed that when Umay leaves a child for a long time, the child gets ill and [[shamanism|shamans]] are involved to call Umay back. The smiling of a sleeping baby shows Umay is near it and crying means that Umay has left. In the view of the [[Kyrgyz people]], Umay not only protects children, but also [[Turkic peoples|Turkic]] communities around the world. At the same time Umay helps people to obtain more food and goods and gives them luck. As Umay is associated with the sun, she is called ''Sarı Kız'' 'Yellow Maiden', and yellow is her colour and symbol. She is depicted as having sixty golden tresses that look like the rays of the sun. She is thought to have once been identical with [[Ot Ene]] of the [[Mongol]]s and [[Altay people|Altay]]. ''Umay'' and ''[[Ece]]'' are also used as female given names in the Republic of [[Turkey]]. ==See also== *[[Tengriism]] == References == == External links == * [http://vlib.iue.it/carrie/texts/carrie_books/paksoy-2/cam1.html Kuyash ham Alav (Sun is also Fire)] ==Bibliography== * [[:tr:Dosya:TurkSoylenceSozlugu.pdf|Turkish Myths Dictionary (Türk Söylence Sözlüğü), Deniz Karakurt]] {{tr}} PDF * Özhan Öztürk. |public_access = Yes |website = |notes = }} '''Yammoune''' is a [[lake]], [[nature reserve]], [[village]] and [[municipality]] situated {{convert|27|km|mi}} northwest of [[Baalbek]] in [[Baalbek District]], [[Baalbek-Hermel Governorate]], [[Lebanon]]. The village has a few hundred inhabitants.<ref name="Boulanger1955">{{cite book|author=Robert Boulanger|title=Lebanon|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nLlMAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=30 October 2012|year=1955|publisher=Hachette}}</ref><ref name="Nashrat al-Āthār wa-al-ʻImārah al-Lubnānīyah"/>
==Ancient temple== There are the ruins of a [[Roman temple|Phoenico-Greco-Roman temple]] in the village that are included in a grouping of [[Temples of the Beqaa Valley]]. It is said to be dedicated to [[Astarte]] or [[Venus]].<ref name="Taylor1971">{{cite book|author=George Taylor|title=The Roman temples of Lebanon: a pictorial guide. Les temples romains au Liban; guide illustré|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ii8NAQAAIAAJ|accessdate=30 October 2012|year=1971|publisher=Dar el-Machreq Publishers}}</ref> Part of two enclosure walls and the temple foundations remain intact.<ref name="Boulanger1955"/> Inscriptions, written in [[Latin]] were found at the temple site.<ref name="Butcher2004">{{cite book|author=Kevin Butcher|title=Roman Syria and the Near East|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YJPn3-rRjC0C&pg=PA230|accessdate=30 October 2012|date=19 February 2004|publisher=Getty Publications|isbn=978-0-89236-715-3|pages=230–}}</ref> [[Ancient Greece|Ancient Greek]] inscriptions were also found.<ref name="Tod1979">{{cite book|author=Marcus Niebuhr Tod|title=The Progress of Greek Epigraphy: The progress of Greek epigraphy, 1937–1953|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uq7kAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=30 October 2012|year=1979|publisher=Ares}}</ref> It is considered likely to be of [[Phoenicia]]n origin.<ref name="CollectifLabourdette2011">{{cite book|author1=Collectif|author2=Jean-Paul Labourdette|author3=Dominique Auzias|title=Liban|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Qo4cwKlBtrcC&pg=PA284|accessdate=30 October 2012|date=1 June 2011|publisher=Petit Futé|isbn=978-2-7469-3699-7|pages=284–}}</ref> [[Ernest Renan]] visited the site and discovered sections of a [[frieze]] and parts of [[pediment]] attributed to the temple. A partly broken [[Cockle (bivalve)|cockle]] [[Seashell|shell]] with a figure of a goddess with outstretched arms was also found recently during ploughing by a [[tractor]].<ref name="Thubron2011">{{cite book|author=Colin Thubron|title=The Hills Of Adonis|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NUNR4wGeKkEC&pg=PA147|accessdate=30 October 2012|date=8 June 2011|publisher=Random House|isbn=978-1-4464-8366-4|pages=147–}}</ref> The ancient name of Yammoune is not known however some have suggested that it was once the location of a [[Festival of Adonis]].<ref name="Nashrat al-Āthār wa-al-ʻImārah al-Lubnānīyah"/><ref>{{cite book|author=Kevin Butcher|title=Roman Syria and the Near East|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YJPn3-rRjC0C&pg=PA460|accessdate=30 October 2012|date=19 February 2004|publisher=Getty Publications|isbn=978-0-89236-715-3|pages=460–}}</ref>
The temple is situated on a hill, approximately {{convert|300|m|ft}} from the main [[Spring (hydrology)|spring]] in the area, the '''Naba al-Arbain'''. It lies next to the lake where it is considered ancient worshippers took [[pilgrimage]] from the temple at [[Afqa]] to purify themselves in the temple waters.<ref name="Nashrat al-Āthār wa-al-ʻImārah al-Lubnānīyah">{{cite book|title=Nashrat al-Āthār wa-al-ʻImārah al-Lubnānīyah|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7HV6AAAAMAAJ|accessdate=30 October 2012|year=2008|publisher=Direction Générale des Antiquités.}}</ref> [[Michael Alouf]] found a statue of [[Adonis]] in the temple, carrying an ear of [[corn]] in one hand and a [[quivver]] and a [[Sheep|lamb]] in the other. He stored the statue at a museum he founded in the ruins of [[Baalbek]]. Alouf also found a [[Roman road]] measuring {{convert|200|m|mi}}, located {{convert|2|km|mi}} southeast of the lake. He also found another square building measuring approximately {{convert|12|m2|ft2}} next to this road. The building was constructed of large stones and an [[Ancient Greece|Ancient Greek]] inscription was found inside. He considered it an ancient [[guardhouse]] or [[watchtower]] for protection of travellers. He suggested that [[oracle]]s were consulted at the temple in connection with [[Queen Zenobia]], who legend tells, sent offerings to the [[goddess]] by placing them on the lake. If the offerings sunk to the floor of the lake, then the goddess had accepted them. If the offerings floated, then they had been rejected and gave a bad [[omen]] to [[Palmyra]] and the surrounding lands.<ref name="AloufRain1999">{{cite book|author1=Michel M. Alouf|author2=Tedd St Rain|title=History of Baalbek|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qiyY1CKE9SIC&pg=PA31|accessdate=30 October 2012|year=1999|publisher=Book Tree|isbn=978-1-58509-063-1|pages=31–}}</ref>
==Geology== The village lies on the Yammoune Fault line, a geological [[Fault (geology)|fault]] responsible for several historical [[earthquake]]s in the area. A new section of the fault was discovered in 2010 by Ata Elias of the [[American University of Beirut]]. They studied samples from a trench in [[Marjahine]] that will allow them to improve dating on historical earthquakes and better predict future ones.<ref>[http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Local-News/Nov/03/Study-uncovers-new-segment-of-Yammouneh-fault-line.ashx#axzz2Ak8tJbZ6 Study uncovers new segment of Yammouneh fault line, The Daily Star (Lebanon), 3 November, 2010.]</ref>
==Lake Yammoune== Lake Yammoune is home to Lebanon's only endemic [[fish]], ''[[Pseudophoxinus libani]]''.<ref name="SOER">[http://test.moe.gov.lb/Documents/SOER%20Chap%205%20reduced.pdf Jaradi, Ghassan Ramasdan., State & Trends of the Lebanese Environment, Chapter 5, Biodiversity and Forests, United Nations Development Programme for the Lebanese Ministry of the Environment, p. 157, 2010.]</ref> In [[Phoenician Mythology]], the goddess [[Astarte]] turned herself into a [[gold]]en fish in Yammoune lake to escape from the vengeance of [[Adonis]]'s wrathful brother [[Typhon]].<ref name="Boulanger1955"/>
The lake is filled from a water cavern to the west of the temple has only one outflow, through a big hole and [[Robert Boulanger]] suggested that it might dry up entirely at the end of summer.<ref name="Boulanger1955"/> The valley of [[Ouyoun Ergush]] leads from Yammoune towards [[Marjhine]].<ref name="Gale2002">{{cite book|author=Gale|title=Who's Who in Lebanon 2003–2004|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=S2dmAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=30 October 2012|date=October 2002|publisher=Gale Group|isbn=978-2-903188-20-7}}</ref>
A network of rock-cut irrigation channels and watercourses lead from Lake Yammoune to provide irrigation for the region of the [[Beqaa Valley]] around Baalbek.<ref name="SimmonsWhayne1944">{{cite book|author1=James Stevens Simmons|author2=Tom French Whayne|author3=Gaylord West Anderson|author4=Harold Maclachlan Horack |author5=United States Surgeon-General's Office: Preventive Medicine Service|title=Global epidemiology: a geography of disease and sanitation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=g5y2AAAAIAAJ|accessdate=30 October 2012|year=1944|publisher=J.B. Lippincott company}}</ref>
==Possible early sanctuary of El== Marvin H. Pope (Yale University) identified the home of [[El (god)|El]] in the [[Ugarit|Ugaritic texts]] of ca. 1200 BCE, described as "at the source[s] of the [two] rivers, in the midst of the fountains of the [two] deeps",<ref>''ARI'', p. 72.</ref> with this famous lake and [[Afqa]], source of the river Adonis on the other side of the mountain, which Pope asserted was closely associated with it in legend.<ref>Pope, "El in the Ugaritic Texts", (''Vetus Testamentum, Supplement'', II) 1955:61ff; approvingly reviewed by [[W. F. Albright]], in ''Journal of Biblical Literature'' '''75'''.3 (September 1956:255-257), who remarked, "However, the identification of El's home with a place in [[Phoenicia]]does not mean that it was not also at a great distance in a cosmic 'never never land'". The "cultic geography" of Adonis, including Afqa, is inspected by Brigitte Soyez in the opening section of ''Byblos et les fêtes des Adonies'' (Leiden: Brill) 1977.</ref>
==Yammoune nature reserve== The area has been classed as a scientific and cultural [[nature reserve]] since 1998 and is known for distinguishing [[juniper]] trees.<ref name="CollectifLabourdette2011"/> The area is popular as a [[hiking trail]].<ref>[http://www.dhiafeeprogram.org/suggested_tours.pdf DHIAFEE Program, Suggested tours.]</ref>
